messageBody:
On 9/12/07, Michael Feathers <mfeathers@...> wrote:

> Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
> >The downside of TDD is that you can end up writing a lot of tests for
> >business code that you quickly throw away and rewrite, so the amount
> >of churn can be quite high.
> >
> >
> I haven't seen that. Maybe we are doing things differently.
>
> One thing that is underemphasized in all of this, though, is TDD's
> effect on design. When you write tests after the fact it's easier to end
> up with classes that are rather monolithic.

True, but I've also seen quite a few examples where TDD-written
classes led to micro-design that forced a lot of refactoring to be
made later as the complexity of the software grows. In particular,
the idea to "do the simplest thing that can possibly work" can be
dangerous, because sometimes, you just know where your code is going
and it's safe to start doing things that might not necessarily be the
simplest thing at the moment but that will save you time in the near
future.

Having said that, it's not very fair to tell you (Michael) about this,
because you're actually one of the few people who have tried to tackle
the hard problem (showing refactoring on real legacy code instead of
advocating TDD on a simple container class).

--
Cédric
Author "Next Generation Testing in Java" (http://tinyurl.com/yvyxa3)
